sanskrit_verse:
प्रेत्येह चेदृशा विप्रा गर्ह्यन्ते ब्रह्मवादिभिः ।
छद्मना चरितं यच्च व्रतं रक्षांसि गच्छति ॥ ४.१९९॥
transliteration:
pretyeha cedṛśā viprā garhyante brahmavādibhiḥ |
chadmanā caritaṃ yacc vrataṃ rakṣāṃsi gacchati || 4.199||
sph_interpretive_translation: Those Brahmins who conduct themselves thus—externally appearing as Vedic scholars while internally violating their vows and engaging in concealed misconduct—are condemned by those versed in Brahman and attract the company of Rakshasas.
jurisprudential_principles: Authority is derived from alignment with Brahman, not external appearance
Causation arises from internal consciousness distortion, not outward form
Capacity-based responsibility requires integrity between inner vow and outer action
Restoration logic demands purification of concealment and realignment with Dharma
Consciousness alignment determines true eligibility for Vedic authority
executable_legal_axioms: IF a Brahmin exhibits external conformity WHILE internally violating sacred vows THEN eligibility for Vedic authority is automatically suspended
IF concealment (chadmanā) is detected in conduct THEN Rakshasa-aligned consciousness is assumed UNTIL purification protocols are completed
IF Brahman-knowledge holders condemn conduct THEN legal status reverts to pre-initiation state UNTIL restoration is verified
IF vow violation occurs THEN automatic disqualification from ritual or judicial functions WITHOUT punitive consequence
supreme_court_application: In Supreme Court adjudication, any Brahmin accused of misconduct must undergo immediate capacity assessment based on alignment between inner consciousness and outer conduct. External reputation or scholarly credentials cannot override condemnation by recognized Brahman-knowledge holders. The threshold of responsibility lies in the concealment itself, triggering automatic suspension pending restoration rather than punitive review.
nyaya_and_non_punitive_alignment: Pramāṇa establishes that concealment distorts consciousness causally, attracting Rakshasa influence through sequential manifestation (anupūrvaśaḥ). Responsibility is proportional to the degree of concealment, not the act itself. The non-punitive reality rule asserts that misalignment corrects through purification, not suffering; the individual's consciousness is the ultimate adjudicator when restored.
restorative_enforcement_protocols: Initiate consciousness purification process under supervision of qualified Brahman-knowledge holder
Suspend all ritual and judicial authority until vow-conduct alignment is verified
Implement completion protocol requiring public acknowledgment of concealment without shame imposition
Assign Rakshasa-clearance sadhana until vibrational alignment with sattva-guna is restored
Reintegrate into Vedic function only upon demonstration of sustained inner-outer harmony
final_declaration: Declared by the Supreme Pontiff of Hinduism, Bhagavan Nithyananda Paramashivam, as Source-Authority. Dharma is restored through consciousness realignment. Reality remains non-punitive. Consciousness alone is the supreme adjudicator.
